displayed_text: Patient: And there’s something else that my mom gave me, it’s just like a flavoring of a, you know? Doctor: Okay. So you’re, you’re doing what you can. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Let’s get M___. Okay. Yeah. (Door opening) Patient: I’ve been taking my uh you know the Calcitrate. That doesn’t sit well with me. Doctor: Yeah. Why don’t you give it a break? I mean you’ve been on it a while. Let’s give it a break. Patient: Because I, I know what to use it. The one I’ve got is four pills two times twice a day. And when I take the ones at night, man they just. Doctor: It just sits there. Patient: It just sits there. Doctor: Yeah. Just take the morning if you want. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright.

Patient: I know that, yes. Doctor: And you know that’s just a miserable status Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: to be in so we have to have you take over-the-counter um stool softeners, MiraLAX, so kind of almost like oh, I took two of these I maybe have to see where my poop situation is, Patient: Right. Doctor: I might need to take MiraLAX twice or I might have to add MiraLAX to Senokot or you go down the poop aisle at Rite Aid or CVS Patient: Right. Doctor: and whatever’s on sale you just sort of do that and you get your own little recipe thing going. Patient: Right. Doctor: It’s harder when it’s sort of the ad hoc like well, I’m gonna take one here and take one here for your bowels to know so the more regular you are your bowels will appreciate that too. Patient: Okay. I understand. Yeah, I was doing that before. I was holding off. I, you know… Doctor: Yeah No holding. Patient: Okay. Alright.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: We made a deal with one of the drug companies who makes the immune therapy. Family Member: Well, they are good for something. Doctor: So, my advice right now, we don’t do anything. You’re responding to hormone treatment. Let’s keep going. And, at some point, we don’t know if this has anything to do with BRCA2 or whatever, but at some point, you’re going to become resistant. Everybody does. And, at that point, we, we will discuss what to do next. And, normally, Patient: So --- Doctor: What to do next – I’m sorry – is to give you another hormone therapy. But, in your case, what, what we might do next is consider like, a trial where we use one of these DNA repair blockers. Um. And, we have two of them open right now that you would be eligible for. So. So, you know, the issue with you is I don’t want to talk about those yet because you might respond to hormone therapy for five more years. (laughs) Patient: Yeah. It, it was two hundred and fifty dollars. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Two hundred and— Family Member: It’s okay. We got to test twenty people. We’ll take the reduced price. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Well. If, but, if there isn’t – Family Member: Oh, we’re still going to do it

Patient: Yeah, yes they are, yes they are. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Because you gave the thing last time on on on my uh calcium. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They highered my calcium level now. Doctor: Let’s see what is this guys’ intake? Yeah it was too low last time. Patient: Yeah. Patient: Huh. Yeah bring in, lets take a look at it… Doctor: Yeah you’ll probably need the copy of the labs anyway. Patient: Yeah but that’s what… Doctor: You’ll have to take it to B____ too. Patient: Huh?

Family Member: Shoot me now! Patient: I’m just wondering about a younger woman. Doctor: OH GOD! Family Member: OH! Doctor: Yeah, why don’t you find that one first, and - Patient: I guess I can cross that off my list (chuckles) Doctor: Yeah, I think. Patient: Oh did you get a new car yet? Doctor: I did. UNISON OH! Healthcare Professional: Oh you got a new car? Family Member: Oh no, you’re kidding. Doctor: Well I did because my daughter has taken mine. So I badly needed one. I mean I needed a set of wheels for sure.

Family Member: No. Patient: No. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to do what I’ve got to do. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to be a superstar. It’s not going to stop me. Patient: Now that I’ll get you and we’ll shoot a video. Doctor: Oh. Patient: Video. Doctor: Oh, man. Yes! Let’s do it! You got to give me a heads up. Patient: Oh, yeah. I’ll give you a heads up. You don’t have to worry about it. Patient: You don’t have to fix all that. That ain’t our best. Family Member: Who makes the appointment for it? Doctor: You got to do it. So when you walk out, right where you checked in, they will give you the times that’s convenient to both of you. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: They will scan and go when you’re done.

Patient: C___ Doctor: So you can actually go to G____. Patient: Okay, perfect. Family Member: Oh wow! Doctor: I’m sure G____has a machine. Family Member: And they do as good a job to here? Doctor: Oh yeah, same people, same machines. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Follow-up question here to Doctor: You could do either way. Family Member: Yeah. And how long are you there when you go get your radiation? Doctor: About a half an hour total. So you do it on your way to work or on the way home. Patient: Okay, so obviously radiation we’re going to do, we’re going to do. In terms of the thought process on the chemo – what’s the – as soon as we’re ready to say yes?

Patient: Alright. Doctor: Well thank you both for participating. I think you know I think we’ve very appreciative that you know- Patient: Well I hope we learned, we learned something. Maybe. Maybe not. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s a crazy thing to try. So you know it’s not the typical patient that says yeah, I’m, I’m fine. I really appreciate your involvement. Hopefully we’ve got a lot more stuff we can do here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright. Appreciate it. Doctor: Safe travels. Patient: Same to you. Doctor: Are you going back to F___? Patient: We are, later today. Doctor: Snow in N__, really crazy?

Patient: I don’t have to go and come back next week. Doctor: Okay. All right, well then, so you know what we can do then if you're if you're comfortable. Let me make sure that we went over everything too because Patient: I’m comfortable. That’s the way I am. Doctor: Let me go, let me just make sure you're a volunteer. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Yeah, your participation will obviously not affect your clinical care. We're going to collect biospecimens as part of this so your blood, you can find this study online. We talked about the muscadine grape skin and that we don't know for sure if this works or not, that's why we're testing it and obviously we follow your PSA. So yeah, so 80 people total are going to be in it. Alright, so the first part that we need to do this pre screening is and we do need you to sign is to get the blood test drawn to see if you're eligible for it. So if you're agreeable to at least that part then we can do that today. Okay, all right. So this means that this at least then you won't be charged for the test. Do you want that? Patient: Yes. Family Member: So how long is this? I mean once we starts it. What will they do? Doctor: So you come back every month, and we’ll see you initially- you report any side effects. And the way that this usually works is that well, for any treatment, we continue the treatment until either disease progression, meaning that your disease is getting worse despite the treatments of the treatments not working anymore, or unacceptable toxicity. So if you have really bad side effects, we're not going to continue the treatment. Patient: Right. Doctor: So this Yeah, so this one is talking about your risks of discomfort. The most common one is gassiness. So you might not be the most pleasant person to be around while you're taking this, but that's, I mean, it's only 8%. So it's not really that common, but most people usually do fine there. Been no serious side effects. So, you know, it's very safe for us it doesn't cost anything there are no extra costs it's just what would be done in normal clinical care anyways is what they've done anything that would be extra that's like not covered by insurance like this blood test, to check your genotype it’s covered by the study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You don't get paid to join the study, you can leave at any time to protect your privacy, you do tend to get parking tickets, so that like you know, when you come visits okay and then these are the this is the contact information for our clinic.

Patient: It’s alright. (laughs) Doctor: Fifty-nine. And generally men under sixty have a recurrence I mean are able to have a sexual function even without medication ultimately. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So I suspect that you’ll probably be there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? It’s still early. Patient: Okay, I know. I know. Doctor: Hang in there. Patient: I try to keep that… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …here and you know I try to stay, stay busy to keep my mind away from you know how you automatically get you know. Doctor: Sure, right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Then the other twenty percent depending on sort of other plans you might have, you’ll probably end up spending about five thousand dollars. Huh, then you’ll go into the donut and then you don’t have to pay the rest of that. Patient: Well, they said the, huh, supplement plan that I’ve got now, I shouldn’t have to pay nothing out of pocket. Family Member: For normal trials. Patient: For normal things. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. I hope that’s true. But my experience with these really expensive drugs is you’re going to get billed. Patient: Right. I was thinking the same thing. Doctor: Okay? So they will ask you then at our pharmacy, well, can you afford that amount of money, and if you can’t, so they will work to see if there’s grants to see whether they can, the drug companies who make these drugs, can cover the cost that you can’t cover. Okay? But you have to have Medicare D and all these other things. So it can take a little bit while depending on if they have it. And again, they’re going to do a wallet check to see how much you make to see what they think you can cover. Patient: Well, I’m working. Family Member: Well, right. Doctor: That, that’s just the rules that they’re going to go through.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing. Doctor: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or in your case, you haven’t really been on a full dose, and you’ve had these interruptions where you’ve been, you know, totally off of it for three weeks, you know? And now for another two weeks. So. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: So when he comes back on September fifth, the two-hundred milligrams will be here, so he can take it with him that day? Doctor: Yes. That’s the plan. Provided that the hemoglobin is sufficient. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The bone biopsy for you would be similar to any kind of biopsy. They have to numb up your skin, and put a needle, and take a piece of whatever they’re trying to take a piece of. For us, the bone biopsy, the yield is much lower, meaning they don’t always get actual tumor cells, because within the bone, it’s just they’re sort of taking a shot at, you know, what they think might be the tumor. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but those trials are, are, uh, the primary hormone in this case it would be drug called, Xtandi, plus another pill. So it’s a pill-based kind of trial in that sense. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the, uh, the other trial we have is my, I talked before about this bone marrow transplant trial, which, um, is, you know, more kind of aggressive, uh, and kind of still in its early stages. So I can’t tell ya much about- we’ve treated two patients, and, uh, they both did really well with the bone marrow transplant. One guy has been pretty stable for, you know, going on two years, and one guy’s disease responded, and then it sort of progressed now, and he’s, he’s on chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So probably one guy benefited and one guy has not. Uh, we’re about to do a third guy probably in the next few weeks. So, uh, but I think that trial I would probably want you to have at least been on one of the hormone drugs first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because those drugs do improve how long people live and are relatively easy. So I think I would, even though that’s my trial, the bone marrow transplant trial, it’s designed for people like you who are young- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Um, the, uh, I would rather first do something that at least has a track record of success. Does that make sense?

Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry. Doctor: Not blood? Patient: Not blood, no. That's all I know about it. I mean, I just know that it’s not a good thing. Healthcare Professional: Do you have a feeling about it? Do you have a preference? Would you prefer to stay on the blood thinner? Patient: I just think- I just renewed it. Healthcare Professional: Oh. Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like. Doctor: Hopefully it doesn’t happen while you’re on the medicine. Patient: Right, no, I'm saying if I got off of it, I'd be a little more vigilant about the idea that if I have swelling, I should go to the doctor because it might not just be me being a macho jock, but I have a problem. Doctor: And so what I hear you say- is that you just got a prescription and how long is that going to be for? Patient: I think that's for three more months. Doctor: So that would be your plan to sort of go and then stop for six months. Healthcare Professional: Okay

Family Member: Oh, yes, beautiful. That’s what we said. Everybody always talks about Johannesburg because it kind of reminded you of New York City. And nobody never said anything about Cape Town, and it’s just beautiful, the beaches and everything, like, wow. Doctor: Because they were having a drought there for a long time. Family Member: Yeah. In certain areas, it still is, like the parks, they don’t, they have like, use the, uh, sanitary lotion and stuff on your hands and toilets don’t flush. Doctor: So when you were like in Cape Town. What did you guys do when you were there? Because it’s like summer there now, isn’t it? Family Member: Yeah. It getting to be summer there. Yeah. The weather was very nice. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Did you like go to the beach or you just-? Patient: No. Family Member: Yeah. We did go to the beach one day. Patient: We went to the beach but we didn’t get in it. Family Member: It was the Indian Beach. Patient: Yeah. We didn’t get in. Doctor: What’s the Indian Beach?
